repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Enterprise and Financial
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project for Algeria were as follows:
            outcomes were deficient, project sustainability was
            uncertain, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the government's objective of moving towards
            a market economy was unlikely to be realized without a
            commitment to shrink the size and favored status of the
            public enterprises sector. The general question is whether
            the Bank should support a reform program that it feels is
            unlikely to meet its stated objectives with the measures
            proposed, yet has enough important elements, such as trade
            and price liberalization and audits of economic agents, that
            need to be carried out in any event. The best solution is
            probably to be more realistic, and therefore more modest, in
            establishing the objectives of the reform program to fit the
            measures that the government is willing to undertake.
            Second, legal reforms are easily undermined by failure to
            promulgate implementing decrees or by other regulations or
            practices that counter the spirit of the reform. While it is
            difficult to ensure that this will not happen, Bank staff
            should be aware of this risk and attempt to protect against
            it to the extent practical, by specifying, for example,
            legal requirements on implementing decrees and institutions.

Algeria - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project

repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project consists of an enterprise component
            interlinked with a financial sector component, accompanied
            by supportive macroeconomic, legal and institutional
            measures.  For the enterprise sector, the program supports
            reforms in five key areas.  First, the rapid introduction of
            competition through the use of market based pricing and
            allocation systems. Second, a proactive approach to the
            development of the private sector.  Third, the
            implementation of the process of "corporatization"
            for public enterprises aimed at separating the roles of the
            State as owner and as regulator of economic activity.
            Fourth, initiating the process of restructuring of public
            enterprises, with a special focus on the largest loss-making
            public enterprises, and fifth, developing a program to
            mitigate the social costs of enterprise restructuring.  In
            the financial sector, the loan will support reforms in four
            areas.  First, limiting the role of the Treasury as an agent
            for financial intermediation and reforming its relationship
            with the Central Bank.  Second, rationalizing interest rate
            and credit policies.  Third, establishing a prudential,
            regulatory and accounting framework for the banking system
            together with a strengthening of the Central Bank, and
            fourth, starting a multi-year program to restructure the
            portfolio of existing banks.
